body:
This change was made in this commit 1605f9e14dbbe58e0b05f746dd9e2dc162e26148

I reverted this commit here

[v1.57.0-beta.5804.b2e9de84f.fix-5762-s3-auth](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-5762-s3-auth/v1.57.0-beta.5804.b2e9de84f.fix-5762-s3-auth/) on branch [fix-5762-s3-auth](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-5762-s3-auth) (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

Can you explain more how you are authenticating? I assume you are setting `env_auth = true`?

Can you give it a go please?

Do you think this is relevant to #5468 ?

Thank you for testing @ThisIsQasim 

@dm3ch as the author of the original patch, can you comment on why you felt it was necessary for your work load? I'm still not sure I understand the issue - thank you :-)

It was some times ago, so I actually don't remember all things.
Original problem (which was fixed by https://github.com/rclone/rclone/commit/1605f9e14dbbe58e0b05f746dd9e2dc162e26148) https://forum.rclone.org/t/shared-credentials-file-config-option-not-works/22318

If I right remember the problem was, that I wasn't able to make work rclone when only `shared_credentials_file` was specified in config file.

Based on commit message it seems, that AWS chained auth provider credentials (that were read from file specified in `shared_credentials_file`) was ignored (and value reassigned to `null`) if AccessKeyID and SecretAuthKey wasn't specified (but when you specifies path to file with credentials it's a normal case if you are not passing AccesskeyID and SecretAuthKey directly).

P.S. I'm ok with reverting my changes in case if auth would still works in case when you just specified `shared_credentials_file` in config. Maybe it worth it to make testcases for all auth flows.

But looking to the documentation and forum post today, I can't understand what make me set `env_auth= true`, cause without that it seems that all should work fine, with unpatched code.

Anyway it seems that maybe it's a good idea to document (or validate during startup), that you shouldn't use `env_auth` and `shared_credentials_file` at the same time.

 P.S. I'm sorry for introducing new bug that days

@d3mch thank you for your reponse.

I've managed to figure out the correct fix for the problem thanks you your additional info.

Can you both, if possible, try this beta

[v1.57.0-beta.5806.6bc2698f0.fix-5762-s3-auth](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-5762-s3-auth/v1.57.0-beta.5806.6bc2698f0.fix-5762-s3-auth/) on branch [fix-5762-s3-auth](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-5762-s3-auth) (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

It shoudl fix both the original issue with IAM Role, and the old issue with shared_credentials_file being ignored. Note you will need `env_auth=true` to use `shared_credentials_file`. This is as documented already.

> P.S. I'm sorry for introducing new bug that days

No problems! I've introduced lots of bugs in rclone ;-) The AWS auth is very complicated and I'm not sure I understand it well enough!

> Maybe it worth it to make testcases for all auth flows.

That would be lovely. They would have to be integration tests to be meaningful which would require all the different auth methods setup for s3 in advance which sounds like hard work, but it would be great to have done that!
I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org/) in 15-30 minutes and released in v1.57

issue.title: activate env auth for irsa

repository.name: mysql-operator
repository.description: Asynchronous MySQL Replication on Kubernetes using Percona Server and Openark's Orchestrator.

issue.body:
In the case of irsa, you need to authenticate with AWS_WEB_IDENTITY_TOKEN_FILE and AWS_ROLE_ARN instead of session_token.

```sh
AWS_ROLE_ARN=arn:aws:iam::<ACCOUNT_ID>:role/<IAM_ROLE_NAME>
AWS_WEB_IDENTITY_TOKEN_FILE=/var/run/secrets/eks.amazonaws.com/serviceaccount/token
```

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/eks/latest/userguide/iam-roles-for-service-accounts-technical-overview.html#pod-configuration

In the case of IRSA, it was necessary to use `AWS_WEB_IDENTITY_TOKEN_FILE` and `AWS_ROLE_ARN` for authentication instead of `AWS_SESSION_TOKEN` environment variable.

In rclone, if `env_auth = true` is set, v1.57 will refer to `AWS_ROLE_ARN` and `AWS_WEB_IDENTITY_TOKEN_FILE` properly.

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5762

issue.title: fix-rcloneImage

repository.name: tidb-operator
repository.description: TiDB operator creates and manages TiDB clusters running in Kubernetes.

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for contributing to TiDB Operator!
Please complete the following template before creating a PR.
Ref: TiDB Operator [CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/pingcap/tidb-operator/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) document
-->

### What problem does this PR solve?
<!--
Please describe the problem AS DETAILED AS POSSIBLE.
Add an ISSUE LINK WITH SUMMARY if exists.

For example:

    Fix the bug that syncing `Backup` CR will crash tidb-controller-manager pod when client TLS feature is enabled.

    Closes #xxx (issue number)
-->

follow doc [restore-data-using-tidb-lightning](https://docs.pingcap.com/tidb-in-kubernetes/stable/restore-data-using-tidb-lightning), when we [Grant permissions by associating IAM with ServiceAccount](https://docs.pingcap.com/tidb-in-kubernetes/stable/grant-permissions-to-remote-storage#grant-permissions-by-associating-iam-with-serviceaccount) and [deploy TiDB Lightning](https://docs.pingcap.com/tidb-in-kubernetes/stable/restore-data-using-tidb-lightning#step-3-deploy-tidb-lightning), we get error below:
![89f51de1-083b-4028-aefa-8e38281bce5b](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13452917/191644249-efced761-a9cf-4bd4-a2cc-e3644dc03b0f.jpeg)

after some test and investigate, we found the default value of `rcloneImage` in `helm inspect values pingcap/tidb-lightning` is rclone/rclone:1.55.1, and there has an [known issue](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5762) in rclone and fixed in rclone v1.57.0

### What is changed and how does it work?
<!--
Please describe the design that your implementation follows AS DETAILED AS POSSIBLE.

For example:

    The root cause is a nil pointer dereferencing. Add a `ptr != nil` check before access members of `ptr` to prevent the crash.
-->

### Code changes

- [ ] Has Go code change
- [ ] Has CI related scripts change

### Tests
<!-- AT LEAST ONE test must be included. -->

- [ ] Unit test <!-- If you added any unit test cases, check this box -->
- [ ] E2E test <!-- If you added any e2e test cases, check this box -->
- [ ] Manual test <!-- If this PR needs manual test, check this box, and add detailed manual test scripts or steps below, so that ANYONE CAN REPRODUCE IT. Ref: https://github.com/pingcap/tidb-operator/pull/3517 -->
- [ ] No code <!-- If this PR contains no code changes, check this box -->

### Side effects

- [ ] Breaking backward compatibility <!-- If this PR breaks things deployed with previous TiDB Operator versions, check this box -->
- [ ] Other side effects: <!-- Any other side effects, such as requiring additional storage / consumes substantial memory / potential reconciliation latency -->

### Related changes

- [ ] Need to cherry-pick to the release branch <!-- If this PR should also appear in the current release branch, check this box -->
- [ ] Need to update the documentation <!-- If this PR introduces new features or changes previous usages, check this box -->

### Release Notes
<!--
If no need to add a release note, just type `NONE` in the following `release-note` block.
If the PR requires additional action from users to deploy the new release, start the release note with "ACTION REQUIRED: ".
-->
Please refer to [Release Notes Language Style Guide](https://github.com/pingcap/tidb-operator/blob/master/docs/release-note-guide.md) before writing the release note.

```release-note

```

body:
Hello, 
I'm running the version 1.59.2 and tried to use the IAM role function (role attached to an AWS EC2 instance) in order to copy files to a AWS S3 bucket but I got an Access Denied, while with aws CLI it worked. I deduced it was not a policy bucket issue. 
my env_auth = true was set . I ran -vv --dump auth and saw the role that meant to be used. I do think it was not used properly by rclone.
I was able to list the content of my bucket but writing into it with env_auth = true.

My workaround was to create an Access keypair
